name: Paper Dosa
history: Paper Dosa is a thin and crispy variant of the traditional South Indian dosa. It is characterized by its large size and paper-thin consistency. Originating from Southern India, it has become popular all over the country for its unique texture and taste.
description: Paper Dosa is an ultra-thin, crispy, and large crepe made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils. It's known for its lightness and is typically served with sambar and chutney. This dosa is a favorite for its delicate texture and impressive size.

instructions.title: Prepare the Batter
instructions.description: Ensure the dosa batter is well fermented and at room temperature.

instructions.title: Heat the Griddle
instructions.description: Heat a large griddle or non-stick pan on medium heat. Sprinkle a few drops of water to check if it's hot enough (the water should sizzle).

instructions.title: Pour and Spread the Batter
instructions.description: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the center of the griddle. Quickly spread it outwards in a circular motion to make an ultra-thin crepe.

instructions.title: Cook the Dosa
instructions.description: Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the dosa. Cook until the dosa is crispy and golden. Do not flip.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Carefully remove the dosa from the griddle without folding. Serve hot with sambar and chutney.

tips: The batter should be of pouring consistency to spread easily.
Use a large griddle to achieve the thin and large size of the paper dosa.
variations: Add finely chopped onions or masala to the dosa for added flavor.
Experiment with different types of chutneys or sambar as accompaniments.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed immediately. Dosa batter can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store unused batter in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a griddle or pan until crispy.

presentationTips: Serve on a large plate to showcase the size of the dosa.
Garnish with a side of coconut chutney and a bowl of sambar.
